Authors:
Ling-Yun Chen, John K Muchuku, Xue Yan, Guang-Wan Hu,
Qing-Feng Wang
Title:
Phylogeography of Haplocarpha rueppelii (Asteraceae) suggests
a geographic barrier between Mts. Kenya and Aberdare since the
Pleistocene
Keywords:
East Africa, afro-montane, afro-alpine, gene flow,
phylogeography, geographic barrier, Haplocarpha rueppelii
Abstract:
Haplocarpha rueppelii is mainly distributed in the alpine
grassland and moorland of East Africa. In this study, we sampled 61
individuals of 6 populations from East Africa, viz.Â Mts. Elgon,
Aberdare, Kenya, Kilimanjaro and Bale mountains. We sequenced 1 nuclear
and 3 chloroplast DNA fragments, and conducted phylogenetic analysis,
divergence time estimation, principal coordinate analysis and gene flow
analysis to investigate the phylogeographic structure of the species.
The results demonstrate that the species consists of two major groups,
one includes the populations from Mts. Elgon, Aberdare and Bale while
the other includes Mts. Kenya and Kilimanjaro. The results also support
that the character of multicellular hairs is mutable and therefore no
change of the taxonomic concept of this species is needed. The species
has established in Mts. Kenya and Aberdare one million years ago,
however, its migration rate between the two mountains was low as showed
by gene flow analysis. Therefore, a barrier for plant migration and gene
flow exists between Mts. Aberdare and Kenya, which is different from
previous studies that show close relationship between the two mountains.
In addition, diversification of this species seems not to be affected by
the East African Rift Valley. This study reveals an unreported
geographic barrier in East Africa using molecular data, and sheds light
on plant phylogeography of the area.
